facts.text: Appeal is Civil Appeal No. 232 of 1964

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 232 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal from Judgment and order dated 23rd October 1960 of Madras High Court in Appeal No. 237 of 1958

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and order dated the 23rd October, 1960 of the Madras High Court in Appeal No. 237 of 1958.

facts.text: Appellant held post of Deputy Tahsildar in Revenue Department of Government of Madras

anchor.surface_text: The appellant held the post of Deputy Tahsildar in the Revenue Department of the Government of Madras.

facts.text: Disciplinary proceedings started against appellant on twelve charges of acceptance of illegal gratification during office as Special Loans Deputy Tahsildar, Cuddalore, South Arcot District

anchor.surface_text: Dis- ciplinary proceedings were started against him on twelve charges of acceptance of illegal gratification during his office as Special Loans Deputy Tahsildar, Cuddalore, South Ascot District.

facts.text: Disciplinary proceedings started against three subordinates on similar charges

anchor.surface_text: Disciplinary proceedings were started against three of his subordinates also on similar charges.

facts.text: Appellant placed under suspension and relieved of duties on May 20, 1949

anchor.surface_text: On May, 20, 1949, he was placed under suspension and relieved of his duties.

facts.text: Disciplinary Proceedings Tribunal directed consolidation and common hearing of enquiries against appellant and other three civil servants

anchor.surface_text: The Disciplinary Proceedings Tribunal directed the companysolidation and companymon hearing of the enquiries against the appellant and the other three civil servants.

facts.text: Appellant asked for permission to engage counsel at the enquiry

anchor.surface_text: The appellant asked for permission to engage a companynsel at the enquiry.

facts.text: Tribunal refused permission by order dated May 31, 1949

anchor.surface_text: By an order dated May 31, 1949, the Tribunal refused to give the permission.

facts.text: Enquiry held on June 13, 14 and 15

anchor.surface_text: The enquiry was held on June 13, 14 and 15.

facts.text: Other three civil servants represented by counsel Sri. Kalyanasundaram at the hearing

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing, the other three civil servants were represented by companynsel, Sri. Kalyanasundaram.

facts.text: On June 13, appellant prayed for adjournment

anchor.surface_text: On June 13, the appellant prayed for an adjournment.

facts.text: Tribunal declined adjournment and allowed appellant to engage Sri. Kalyanasundaram

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal declined to grant the adjournment and told the appellant that he was at liberty to engage Sri. Kalyanasundaram as his companynsel.

facts.text: Appellant availed services of Sri. Kalyanasundaram and was represented by him throughout enquiry

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereupon availed himself of the services of Sri. Kalyanasundaram, and was represented by him throughout the enquiry.

facts.text: Tribunal submitted report on June 30 stating charges proved and recommending dismissal

anchor.surface_text: On June 30, the Tribunal submitted a report stating that the charges against the appellant were proved and recommending his dismissal.

facts.text: Government issued notice on September 16 to show cause why dismissed

anchor.surface_text: On September 16, the Government issued a numberice to him asking him to show cause why he should number be dismissed from service.

facts.text: Appellant submitted written representation on November 12, 1949

anchor.surface_text: On November 12, 1949, he submitted his written representation.

facts.text: Government directed dismissal from service with effect from May 20, 1949 on October 17, 1950

anchor.surface_text: On October 17, 1950, the Government directed that he be dismissed from service with effect from May 20, 1949.

facts.text: Appellant instituted suit for declaration that dismissal order dated October 17, 1950 is illegal and void

anchor.surface_text: The appellant instituted the suit asking for a declaration that the order dated October 17, 1950 dismissing him from service is illegal and void.

facts.text: Trial Court dismissed the suit

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court dismissed the suit,

facts.text: High Court of Madras affirmed the decree on appeal

anchor.surface_text: and, this decree was affirmed on appeal by the High Court of Madras.

facts.text: Appellant appeals to this Court by special leave

anchor.surface_text: The appellant number appeals to this Court by special leave.

facts.text: Court finds no conflict of interests between appellant and other three civil servants

anchor.surface_text: There was numberconflict of interests between him and the other three civil servants.

facts.text: Enquiry continued for three days

anchor.surface_text: The enquiry companytinued for three days.

facts.text: Not proved that counsel unable to conduct defence properly

anchor.surface_text: It is number proved that companynsel was unable to companyduct the defence properly.
The appellant number appeals to this Court by special leave.

Counsel for the appellant submitted that in view of the refusal of the appellants prayer for engaging a counsel of his own choice and his prayer for adjournment of the hearing on June 13, 1949, the appellant had been denied a reasonable opportunity to defend himself against the charges.

concepts.interpretation: No denial of reasonable opportunity as no conflict of interests, same counsel permitted to represent, enquiry lasted three days, no proof of improper defence, no prejudice alleged even in written representation.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the appellant had reasonable opportunity to defend himself against the charges.

concepts.interpretation: Dismissal order with retrospective effect is composite and separable; prospective part valid even if retrospective direction invalid; order effective from date of order (October 17, 1950).

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: n on the first companytention. Counsel for the appellant companyceded that if the respondents second companytention is accepted, the appeal must fail.

concepts.unlisted_description: Principle that retrospective dismissal orders are severable, with the forward-dated dismissal remaining valid.

anchor.surface_text: The two parts of this composite order are separable. The first part of the order operates as a dismissal of the appellant as from October 17, 1950.

concepts.interpretation: Invalidity of retrospective operation does not affect validity of prospective dismissal; court can uphold severable valid part.

concepts.unlisted_description: Administrative orders like dismissal are severable into valid and invalid parts.

issues.text: Whether the appellant had been denied a reasonable opportunity to defend himself against the charges in view of the refusal of the appellant's prayer for engaging a counsel of his own choice and his prayer for adjournment of the hearing on June 13, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant submitted that in view of the refusal of the appellants prayer for engaging a companynsel of his own choice and his prayer for adjournment of the hearing on June 13, 1949, the appellant had

issues.text: Whether the order of dismissal dated October 17, 1950 having been passed with retrospective effect is illegal and inoperative.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant next contended that the order of dismissal dated October 17, 1950 having been passed with re- trospective effect is illegal and inoperative.

issues.text: Whether the order of dismissal is valid and effective as from October 17, 1950 even if the retrospective effect is invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The two parts of this composite order are separable. The first part of the order operates as a dismissal of the appellant as from October 17, 1950.

issues.text: Whether the two parts of the composite dismissal order are separable such that invalidity of the retrospective part does not affect the prospective part.

anchor.surface_text: The two parts ,of this companyposite order are separable. The first part of the order ,operates as a dismissal of the appellant as from October 17, 1950. The invalidity of the second part of the order, assuming this part to be invalid, does number affect the first part of the order.

arguments.claim: In view of the refusal of the appellant's prayer for engaging a counsel of his own choice and his prayer for adjournment of the hearing on June 13, 1949, the appellant had been denied a reasonable opportunity to defend himself against the charges.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant submitted that in view of the refusal of the appellants prayer for engaging a companynsel of his own choice and his prayer for adjournment of the hearing on June 13, 1949, the appellant had been denied a reasonable opportunity to defend himself against the charges.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: tunity to defend himself against the charges. We are number inclined to accept this submission. There was numberconflict of interests between him and

arguments.court_reasoning: No conflict of interests between appellant and other three civil servants; counsel for others allowed to represent appellant; enquiry continued for three days; not proved that counsel was unable to conduct defence properly; appellant did not allege prejudice in written representation dated November 12, 1949.

arguments.claim: The order of dismissal dated October 17, 1950 having been passed with retrospective effect is illegal and inoperative.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant next companytended that the order of dismissal dated October 17, 1950 having been passed with re- trospective effect is illegal and inoperative.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: tober 17, 1950. The invalidity of the second part of the order, assuming this part to be invalid, does number affect the first part of the order. The

arguments.court_reasoning: Even assuming retrospective part invalid, the order is separable and valid prospectively from October 17, 1950.

arguments.claim: The order of dismissal with retrospective effect as from the date of the suspension is valid in its entirety.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the respondent submitted 1 the order of dismissal with retrospective effect as from the date of the suspension is valid in its entirety,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: is valid and effective as from October 17, 1950. The High Court accepted the first companytention, a

arguments.court_reasoning: Court declines to express opinion on first contention as second contention accepted.

arguments.claim: In any event, the order is valid and effective as from October 17, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: and 2 in any event, the order is valid and effective as from October 17, 1950.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: is valid and effective as from October 17, 1950. The High Court accepted the first companytention, and declined to express any opinion on the second c

arguments.court_reasoning: Second contention sound; order is composite with separable parts; first part dismisses from October 17, 1950; invalidity of retrospective part does not affect prospective part.

arguments.claim: The two parts of this composite order are separable. The first part of the order operates as a dismissal of the appellant as from October 17, 1950. The invalidity of the second part of the order, assuming this part to be invalid, does not affect the first part of the order.

anchor.surface_text: The two parts ,of this companyposite order are separable. The first part of the order ,operates as a dismissal of the appellant as from October 17, 1950.

arguments.qualifiers: assuming this part to be invalid

arguments.claim: In Hemanta Kumar v. S. N. Mukherjee, the Calcutta High Court upheld the valid prospective part of a retrospective suspension order while quashing the retrospective part.

anchor.surface_text: We may number numberice the cases relied on by companynsel for the appellant. In Hemanta Kumar v. S. N. Mukherjee 1 , the Calcutta High Court had occasion to companysider an order dated April 29, 1952 by which a civil servant had been placed under suspension with retrospective effect from January 16, 1951.

arguments.court_reasoning: This decision supports severability and is against the appellant.

arguments.claim: In Abdul Hamid v. The District School Board and Sudhir Ranjan Haldar v. State of West Bengal, the Calcutta High Court held that retrospective dismissal orders stand or fall in toto, but this reasoning is incorrect.

anchor.surface_text: In Abdul Hamid v. The District School Board, 24-Parganas 2 , the Calcutta High Court had occasion to companysider an order dated April 18, 1952 discharging a teacher... The order must stand or fall In toto.

arguments.court_reasoning: Unable to agree; order of dismissal with retrospective effect is in substance dismissal from date of order with superadded retrospective direction; two parts clearly severable; no reason why first part not given effect; court can give effect to valid severable part.

arguments.claim: Cases relied on by counsel for the appellant support that retrospective dismissal orders are wholly invalid.

anchor.surface_text: We may number numberice the cases relied on by companynsel for the appellant.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ng that the dismissal from the period from July 15. 1951 up to April 17, 1952 was invalid, the High Court also held that the order of dismissal was en

arguments.court_reasoning: Hemanta supports severability; disagree with Abdul Hamid and Sudhir Ranjan that order stands or falls in toto; parts severable.

arguments.claim: The High Court accepted the first contention of the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court accepted the first companytention, and declined to express any opinion on the second companytention.

holdings.text: We are satisfied that the appellant had reasonable opportunity to defend himself against the charges.

anchor.surface_text: Even in his written representation dated November 12, 1949, the appellant did not allege that he was prejudiced in his defence. We are satisfied that the appellant had reasonable opportunity to defend himself against the charges.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No conflict of interests with co-enquiry participants; tribunal permitted shared counsel; three-day enquiry; no proof counsel conducted defence improperly; no prejudice alleged in representation.

holdings.text: In our opinion, the second contention of the respondent is sound, and in this view of the matter, we decline to express any opinion on the first contention.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the second contention of the respondent is sound, and in this view of the matter, we decline to express any opinion on the first contention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts respondent's alternative argument that order valid prospectively from date of order regardless of retrospective effect.

holdings.text: The two parts of this composite order are separable. The first part of the order operates as a dismissal of the appellant as from October 17, 1950. The invalidity of the second part of the order, assuming this part to be invalid, does not affect the first part of the order.

anchor.surface_text: The two parts of this composite order are separable. The first part of the order operates as a dismissal of the appellant as from October 17, 1950. The invalidity of the second part of the order, assuming this part to be invalid, does not affect the first part of the order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order in substance has two severable parts: prospective dismissal and superadded retrospective direction; court can enforce valid prospective part even assuming retrospective invalid; distinguishes contrary High Court precedents.

holdings.text: The order of dismissal as from October 17, 1950 is valid and effective. The appellant has been lawfully dismissed, and he is not entitled to claim that he is still in service.

anchor.surface_text: The order of dismissal as from October 17, 1950 is valid and effective. The appellant has been lawfully dismissed, and he is not entitled to claim that he is still in service.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Flows from severability holding; prospective operation validates dismissal despite potential invalidity of retrospective element.

precedents.citation: Hemanta Kumar v. S. N. Mukherjee 1

anchor.surface_text: Hemanta Kumar v. S. N. Mukherjee 1 , the Calcutta High Court had occasion to companysider an order dated April 29, 1952 by which a civil servant had been placed under suspension with retrospective effect from January 16, 1951.

precedents.case_name: Hemanta Kumar v S N Mukherjee
precedents.cited_proposition: order of suspension with retrospective effect is invalid for the retrospective period but the order is valid and effective from the date of the order
precedents.cited_holding: the order of suspension was valid and effective as and from April 29, 1952 and this part of the order should be upheld

precedents.citation: Abdul Hamid v. The District School Board, 24-Parganas 2

anchor.surface_text: Abdul Hamid v. The District School Board, 24-Parganas 2 , the Calcutta High Court had occasion to companysider an order dated April 18, 1952 discharging a teacher employed by a District School Board from service with effect from July 15, 195

precedents.case_name: Abdul Hamid v The District School Board 24-Parganas
precedents.cited_proposition: order of dismissal with retrospective effect is entirely bad even from the date of order and must stand or fall in toto
precedents.cited_holding: the order of dismissal was entirely bad and was number effective even from April 18, 1952. The order must stand or fall In toto

precedents.citation: Sudhir Ranjan Haldar v. State of West Bengal

anchor.surface_text: Sudhir Ranjan Haldar v. State of West Bengal  . With respect, we are unable to agree with this line of reasoning.

precedents.case_name: Sudhir Ranjan Haldar v State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: similar observations that an order must stand or fall in toto

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is dismissed. There will be numberorder ,as to companyts.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; order of dismissal upheld as valid and effective from October 17, 1950
